titleInfo.subTitle: Robert C. West oral history interview, 1992

name.description: Robert C. West (1913-2001) received bachelor's and master's degrees from the University of California, Los Angeles, finishing in 1938. He entered the Ph.D. program at the University of California, Berkeley, where he studied under the prominent geographer, Carl Sauer. West served as a cartographer in the Office of Strategic Services, a forerunner to the Central Intelligence Agency, for four years during World War II. After the war, he quickly completed his dissertation on colonial mining in Northern Mexico, receiving his Ph.D. in 1946. West worked as a cultural geographer with the Smithsonian Institution in Mexico City for two years before joining the faculty of the Department of Geography and Anthropology at Louisiana State University in 1948, specifically teaching courses on Central and South America. He was named a Boyd Professor in 1970 and retired in 1980.

mods.abstract: Session I, which is indexed, concerns West's education under Carl Sauer at the University of California, Berkeley; his decision to study geography at the University of California, Los Angeles; his work with Clifford Zierer at UCLA; and his interest in the geography of Mexico.; Session II, which is indexed, covers West's work with Carl Sauer, his thesis on Spanish settlement in Mexico near silver mines, his time making maps and surveying European map collections for the Office of Strategic Services during World War II, his study of the Tarascan Indians of Mexico for the Smithsonian Institution, his interest in chinampas farming and related work with Pedro Armillas, and various approaches and theories in the study of geography.; Session III, which is transcribed, describes Carl Sauer and Alfred Kroeber at Berkeley, West's arrival at Louisiana State University, and topics in the study of geography.; Session IV, which is transcribed, concerns West's research on salt marshes in South America, French and Spanish surnames in Louisiana, agriculture in Mexico and South America, and theories on overpopulation in pre-Columbian Mexico.; Session V, which is transcribed, describes West's research on vegetation in the Mexican state of Tabasco, cacao plantations around Comalcalco, colleagues he worked with in Mexico and their research interests, interviewing locals in Mexico on agricultural practices, and his own methods for doing field work.; Session VI, which is indexed, concerns West's methods for doing field work, especially his use of photography, and changes in crops, chinampas farming, and agricultural methods in Mexico.; Session VII, which is indexed, discusses West's work on the geography of the Mexican state of Sonora, faculty members in LSU's Department of Geography and Anthropology, some of West's former students and their research, and a summation of West's research methods.
